citations.narrative:
In the blue and yellow macaw indoor housing, the overhead lighting bulbs were fluorescents with no covers and did not
appear to have the thin sleeves on them. Glass lightbulbs directly above animal enclosures that have mesh ceilings
should have covers to prevent injuries to the birds if the bulbs break. Housing facilities must be designed and constructed
so that they are structurally sound and protect the birds from injury.
Correct before the next scheduled Re-License inspection.

In the Great Horned Owl enclosure, there were recently replaced mesh screens in raw wood frames that had not been
sealed, so they could not be cleaned and or sanitized effectively. Interior surfaces that come in contact with birds must be
constructed in a manner and made of materials that allow them to be readily cleaned and/or sanitized.
Correct before the next scheduled Re-License inspection.
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class “C” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the
applicant.
All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspections or by 21 April, 2024 or the applicant will forfeit the license fee
and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License Inspection.
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires on 8 March, 2024.
n

narrative:
3.150(a) 
   
Facilities, general. 
In the blue and yellow macaw indoor housing, the overhead lighting bulbs were fluorescents with no covers and did not 
appear to have the thin sleeves on them. Glass lightbulbs directly above animal enclosures that have mesh ceilings 
should have covers to prevent injuries to the birds if the bulbs break. Housing facilities must be designed and constructed 
so that they are structurally sound and protect the birds from injury. 
 
Correct before the next scheduled Re-License inspection. 
3.150(c) 
   
Facilities, general. 
In the Great Horned Owl enclosure, there were recently replaced mesh screens in raw wood frames that had not been 
sealed, so they could not be cleaned and or sanitized effectively. Interior surfaces that come in contact with birds must be 
constructed in a manner and made of materials that allow them to be readily cleaned and/or sanitized. 
 
Correct before the next scheduled Re-License inspection. 
 
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class “C” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the 
applicant. 
 
All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspections or by 21 April, 2024 or the applicant will forfeit the license fee 
and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License Inspection. 
 
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires on 8 March, 2024.
